summary: A new English teacher, John Keating (Robin Williams), is introduced to an all-boys preparatory school that is known for its ancient traditions and high standards. He uses unorthodox methods to reach out to his students, who face enormous pressures from their parents and the school. With Keating's help, students Neil Perry (Robert Sean Leonard), Todd Anderson (Ethan Hawke) and others learn to break out of their shells, pursue their dreams and seize the day.

Thought-provoking but oversimplified 

"Dead Poets Society" is definitely worth watching, but it loses a star due to two main points:

1 - Mr. Keating's encouragement for students to follow their dreams doesn't prepare them for the real-life consequences of choosing a less conservative path.

2 - The movie's portrayal of conservative authorities as heartless and irrational is an unfair oversimplification, as their emotions and reasons for advising against taking risks can be more complex.

The film's unrealistic nature stems from Mr. Keating being too left and other conservatives being too right. A more balanced approach would involve someone in the middle, tailoring their advice to each individual's personality and situation, such as strengthening Neil emotionally before encouraging him to pursue his dreams. A one-size-fits-all solution feels oversimplified.

Nevertheless, "Dead Poets Society" is a thought-provoking, well-directed, and well-produced movie that deserves 4 stars.

Dead Poets Society is a beautiful and heartbreaking film, especially in hindsight of circumstances around Robin Williams' tragic passing. It's got some problematic moments, mostly surrounding the "relationship" between Knox and Chris, which varies from mildly creepy to outright predatory, and because of which Knox never suffers any consequences, of course. It would have been nice for a film with so much foresight and nuanced perspective to handle this topic a little more gracefully.

The rest of the subplots are generally really satisfying and the film does a good job of making relatively-low-stakes situations feel like life-or-death (up until the actual life-or-death situations show up, of course). The school administrators are written with a cold callousness that boils your blood and gets you emotionally-sided with our group of kids. And it was really refreshing to see all these kids actually look like kids, acne and all.

This is an extraordinary, flawed, beautiful film which I believe will only get better with age.

Once again, God has the most impeccable timing of bringing me films to see at EXACTLY the impeccable timing God wants me to see them. This is the case in point of my watching of DEAD POETS SOCIETY. It's a film about "carpe diem" ("seize the day") but for me, the film elevates the viewer to "carpe vita tua" ("seize your life") while one still has all those "days to seize" of one's inevitably short life.

DEAD POETS SOCIETY is directed by Peter Weir (WITNESS [1985] and FEARLESS [1993]) and stars Robin Williams as a very unorthodox teacher, John Keating, in a very orthodox school, and features a cast of very talented young actors. The students have never been taught by anyone quite like Keating. The first day in Keating's class, Keating has every student rip out (actually, tear and shred) the pages of the introduction, "Understanding Poetry," to the book they will be studying. Keating in his unorthodox teaching proceeds to help each and every student find their own voice not only in poetry but also in their own lives. This is vital because there are three students highlighted in this film who need to find their voices. There is Neil Perry (Robert Sean Leonard) who wants to be an actor though his father wants him to be anything but an actor. There is Knox Overstreet (Josh Charles) who wants the most beautiful girl he ever saw to fall in love him even though she is way out of his league. And then there is Todd Anderson (Ethan Hawke) who is painfully shy and feels a deep sense of low self-worth (boy, can I identify with that!). It's Anderson, in particular, of great interest to me, because what Keating is able to teach Anderson is something Keating teaches all of us, i.e., "carpe vita tua" ("seize your life").

The late Robin Williams is who we all know (knew) and love (loved), and his performance in DEAD POETS SOCIETY is unlike anything Williams has (had) shown us before. The "manic" Williams is the "merciful" Keating in Williams' great performance in this film. John Keating teaches unorthodox methods that the faculty deem careless and irresponsible. What the faculty can't grasp is that the rigid rules and regulations they impose on their students is what will impose on their students conforming to rigid rules and regulations and, basically, their students becoming robots. But that's what the faculty wants, i.e., they want robots because then they won't be challenged when it comes to their rigid rules and regulations. In school or not, the world wants robots, too. Robots have no freedom to be who they are created by God to be. A school (or a world) that turns out robots at graduation is a school (or a world) that turns out robots to live robotic lives. Keating won't have that imposed on his students, and he goes to great lengths to ensure his students are exactly who God created them to be, i.e., precious and free. Keating probably wouldn't admit he's doing God's Work in DEAD POETS SOCIETY, but this is EXACTLY what Keating is doing, i.e., doing God's Work with his students to teach them, "do not conform to the pattern of this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind. Then you will be able to test and approve what God's will is—his good, pleasing and perfect will" (Romans 12:2). Keating is "good, pleasing, and perfect" to God for Keating is doing God's Will with God's Students.

Perry auditions for a play and gets the role of Puck in William Shakespeare's A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM. Sidebar: As an actor myself, I remember doing a Puck soliloquy in an acting class and because my elements are fire and wind, Puck's elements, one of the students in my class exclaimed, "Timothy, that's the best Puck I've ever seen!" Perry defies his father by playing free-spirited Puck and because of this, Perry's NOT free-spirited father tells Perry he will be leaving this orthodox school to go into another orthodox military academy. Perry can't accept the caged "orthodox life" that Keating taught him never to live, so Perry accepts the free "unorthodox death." Overstreet conforms not to this world and pursues his romantic interests toward the most beautiful girl he ever saw and in a very touching scene, when Overstreet is in the audience next to her watching Perry in his play and grabs for her hand and probably because of the spell the play casts, she's led to grasp Overstreet's hand right back. And then there is Anderson. Thank God director Weir understands that Anderson is his shining "pupil" in DEAD POETS SOCIETY. When Keating is let go from his teaching position, it is Anderson who makes the first move to not conform to this decision. One of Keating's teaching methods was to have each of his students stand on a desk so they could get a newer and better perspective on their lives from Up There. When Keating is leaving the class for the last time, it is Anderson who is the first one who stands up on his desk and says to Keating, "O Captain, my Captain" (from a poem by Walt Whitman, what Keating taught his students to call him). It is also Anderson who director Weir gives us as the final image of the film, so that we are left with, "Anderson, O Captain, my Captain, we see you up on that desk from where we are sitting, and we join you Up There!" Anderson is now "carpe diem" ("seize the day") when Keating leaves but, more importantly in that final image now and forever, Anderson is "carpe vita tua" ("seize your life").

With an Oscar-winning screenplay by Tom Schulman, DEAD POETS SOCIETY is a film where we are all invited to graduate, in school or not, to a higher plane in life and a higher life on a plane of "seizing your life." It is a film that invites us to be fearless, daring, courageous, to "not conform to this world but renew your mind." Robin Williams in an inspiring performance gives us John Keating who takes the minds and hearts of each of his students and gives them an "O Captain, my Captain" who they can follow to nonconformity, In doing so, we also can follow Keating, in school or not, to leave behind our robotic lives and discover what is God's "good, pleasing and perfect will," and this will is to "seize our lives" and NOT be held captive to any "O Captain, my Captain" who wants to teach us to conform.

"Rules were made to be broken." Indeed, they were! But we don't break rules just to break them. We break rules to be taught by God (and Keating) that we "break free" from conformity, because we won't be robots for anyone when we "seize your life."

I am a huge fan of Dead Poets Society ever since I first saw it a little more than three years ago. While the movie does wrap you up in a cozy blanket of boarding school shenanigans in a picturesque setting for the first one and a half hours only to rip out your heart and step on it during the last thirty minutes, it does so absolutely beautifully. The scenery is marvelous, the soundtrack is beautiful and the characters are engaging and relatable. Robin Williams' performance is, of course, an absolute highlight.

While it might have its schmaltzy moments, and contains the same message pretty much every big Robin Williams film contains, Dead Poets Society contains enough realistic writing and affecting performances to give it a life of its own. The late, great Williams, who was emotionally affected by a divorce he was going through at the time, is as likeable here as ever, and despite his limited screen time, he dominates the scenes he's in, and while his usually explosive comedic persona is noticeably reigned in here, he still gets most of the films funniest lines. His unique teaching style and reluctance to adhere to convention is what earns him the respect and adoration of his students, and while they question what he says throughout, they do grasp the central theme, and that's what makes his teaching so compelling. It's all about being an individual, and viewing poetry as a means of self-expression, not just regurgitating lines of dialogue and analysing them. Things slow down considerably in the 3rd act, but the final scene is an all-time classic, and once its over its hard not to have a smile on your face. It's a standout film in Robin William's oeuvre, and one that, as usual, he completely made his own.

Unconventional teacher John Keating, Robin Williams, disrupts the lives of his students at Welton Academy as he forces them to embrace poetry and do whatever they want because of the credos he pushes on them. The boys are negatively affected as Neil Perry, Robert Sean Leonard, decides to appear in a play against the wishes of his father Thomas, Kurtwood Smith, leading to disastrous consequences. He does allow the shy Todd Anderson, Ethan Hawke, to come out of his shell by embarrassing him and forcing him to make up a poem in front of his classmates. The other student in the group who receives their own subplot is Knox Overstreet, Josh Charles, who falls in love with blonde cheerleader Chris Noel, Alexandra Powers, despite her being in a committed relationship. In the end the boys stand up for the teacher who has brainwashed them with a symbolic gesture but he is still fired due to their actions.

Williams is so manic and intense in his performance while never quite convincing you that his character is genuine in his desire to educate these young men that it is difficult to follow him. We don't see what would inspire such devotion in this group of boys as they seem more like fevered cult members than diligent students. We are clearly meant to be charmed by the antics of the lead character but Williams is more annoying than hilarious or witty and we find ourselves turned off by his constant calls to action and attempts to turn these young men into radicals. I can't say the rest of the cast are of any particular note as Hawke and Leonard fill their roles nicely but don't stand out like Pamela Franklin or Lee Grant in far more original films. 

From there the rest of the film doesn't quite work as "Carpe diem" sounds less inspiring coming out of the mouth of a man who we are never really drawn to. The Tom Schulman screenplay doesn't help as it fails to be truly inspiring and instead inserts cheap platitudes in favor of scenes that would really explore youthful angst and the negative influence of a repressive society. The concerns of the boys also seem trivial while the film treats them as though they are paramount. If the film were to be made today Perry and Anderson would definitely be homosexual and while I understand why that would not have been a plot point in a mainstream film from 1989 I do think this would have been a more compelling struggle. The tragic event that punctuates the film was unearned and I felt horribly emotionally manipulated as the film portrays a confused teenager as a martyr for his beliefs. The only fascinating touch added to the scene is that Weir allows us to witness the devastated expression on Perry's father's face and just for a moment the film explore a difficult issue with some depth and perception.

It's unfortunate that many love this film and hold it up as being genuinely inspirational when it is so fake and manufactured. Peter Weir is a director capable of producing films with real emotional and dramatic heft such as The Truman Show (1998) and Fearless (1993) but his talents are no use when he is working with such a phony script and while the film may look good it has little to say. This is not one worth devoting over two hours of your time to.

Dead Poets Society: "Seizing the Day" One Heartstring at a Time
Dead Poets Society will leave you feeling like you can seize more than just your day. If there had ever been a movie that urges you to feel every possible emotion, Dead Poets Society would be that film. Not only is it solemn and heartbreaking, it is witty and empowering.
	Set in the Northeast in the latter end of the 1950's, Dead Poets Society is about a group of students at an all-boys prep school, Welton Academy. Welton is an extremely elite and conservative academy with strict rules, leaving no room for nonsense. Any attempt at frivolity is squandered by stern parents or high-strung faculty. The lives of the group of students is altered when they meet their English professor, John Keating (Robin Williams). John Keating, an alumnus of Welton, is a poetry loving, independent thinking activist, who expands the minds of his students through his unorthodox teaching methods. Through those unorthodox teaching methods, Keating instills in the group of students the mindset of "carpe diem", or "seize the day". The "seize the day" mindset really comes into play in the students' lives when they revive an old school club that Keating founded during his time as a student, the Dead Poets Society. The Dead Poets Society is a group that meets to, "suck the marrow out of life" through poetry. Through the experiences that the group of students has with the freshly revived Dead Poets Society and their beloved professor John Keating, this group of formerly humdrum students begin to learn what it means to really live life.
	Major themes of the movie include independent thinking, benefits of non-conformity, and carpe diem (seize the day). All of the major themes of the movie are represented in a smaller way through certain teaching exercises of John Keating. For example, the theme of independent thinking is represented at the beginning of the new semester. He has the students tear out the introduction of their poetry textbook on the grounds that he believes the authors views on poetry are, "excrement." The theme of non-conformity is represented during one scene of the film when Keating takes the class outside to the courtyard. He has each student walk in their own unique way to demonstrate the point that everyone has their own way of doing things. When one of the students chooses to stand in place as opposed to walking with the rest of the class, Keating's response is, "thank you...you just illustrated the point. Swim against the stream." 
Dead Poets Society is reminiscent of other "inspiring teacher movies" such as Mr. Holland's Opus or Freedom Writers, in the way that in the beginning the authoritative figure isn't necessarily well received. The students don't necessarily connect with the teacher right in the beginning, but over time, the teacher is able to uplift and inspire those in their sphere of influence.
The director of Dead Poets Society, Peter Weir, could not have had a better compliment to the film than having Robin Williams. Robin Williams was absolutely magnificent as the English professor John Keating. Compared to other films that Robin Williams has acted in such as Good Will Hunting and Mrs. Doubtfire, he received relatively small amounts of screen time. However, the smaller amount of screen time did not hinder the film or his performance, it enhanced it. Even with Williams not eating up the screen time, he still managed to beautifully commandeer the film. Robin Williams made you feel as though John Keating was worthy enough to enroll yourself at Welton Academy just so you could find out for yourself what exactly it means to "seize the day."
	Dead Poets Society leaves you feeling as though there is much more to life than has previously met your eye. For those who feel they are in a stagnant rut of life, one of going through the motions and conforming to society, Dead Poets Society is the chicken soup for your soul. Upon finishing the movie, I feel like I have a lot of life in me to give. This movie will influence your thinking in a way that you will not want to just do life, but to actually live life.

A movie becomes iconic if it changes the way that you think and influences viewers to feel powerful emotions. Dead Poets Society undoubtedly succeeds in accomplishing these two things. Thousands of viewers over the past couple decades have been affected by the moving messages that are shared in this award-winning movie, but there are some elements of character and plot development that were not executed quite as well as they could have been. The promenade of pretty monologues greatly affect this movie in that they seek to mask these developmental errors.

This emblematic coming of age film takes place in a posh all-boys school in New England. Set in the late 1950's, Welton Academy is traditional and very serious until alumnus John Keating (Robin Williams)  is hired to be the new English professor. On the first day of class, Keating takes the students on a field trip to a display case and instills in their minds the urgency of "carpe diem". This initial scene includes an aforementioned pretty monologue' that rolls like liquid gold off of Mr. Keating's tongue and into the ears and hearts of student and audience member alike. This speech is excellently performed by Williams, however there is something about it that doesn't quite sit right. The creepy way that he whispers "carpe diem" and the fact that he has the boys lean uncomfortably close to the pictures reminds us how little we actually know about Keating's curious background as a former student at Welton. The mystery develops throughout the movie as the boys discover Mr. Keating's involvement with the original Dead Poets Society. Though this beginning monologue is powerful and will motivate you to seize the day, the wacky undertones allude to a cryptic past that begs to be explained, but is not made clear in the movie. 

The story continues with well-worded inspiring passages scattered throughout every other scene or so and the boys begin to adjust their lives to more fully seize the day. One student, Knox Overstreet (Josh Charles) becomes a hopeless romantic as he pursues a girl he hardly even knows, Chris. Knox takes many risks to try to woo Chris, including sneaking off of school property and riding his bike to town just to stare at her awkwardly from afar. This covetous behavior reaches its climax at a party, where drunken Knox "makes a move" on Chris and then gets punched several times by Chris' overprotective boyfriend Chet. Mr. Keating condones Knox's actions and tells the students that, "the purpose of language is to woo women." Knox proceeds to write a cheesy poem which he delivers to Chris and the entire scene is overdone and cliche. While a coming of age movie is not truly complete without a romance, the relationship between Knox and Chris could have been developed in a way that was more unique, and Knox's character development could have been more relatable.

Neil Perry (Robert Sean Leonard) decides to implement Mr. Keating's teachings by auditioning for a play, despite his father's disapproval. He gets the role as Puck in Midsummer Night's Dream which sparks an argument between him and his father and Neil goes to Mr. Keating to find guidance. Mr. Keating shares beautifully phrased counsel telling Neil that he should confront his father and tell him how passionate he is about acting. Neil attempts to communicate how he feels to his father, but is unsuccessful. This contention eventually leads to Mr. Perry threatening to take Neil out of Welton Academy and enroll him in a military school. Neil, feeling trapped, decides to commit suicide. After reviewing the events leading up to Neil's death it may seem plausible for him to take this course of action, however most audience members are left feeling confused at how the situation escalated so quickly. It seems like at one second the advice that Mr. Keating has given will mend the relationship between father and son, but then all of the sudden Neil is dead. As I have talked to other people about this movie, the most common observation I hear is that Neil's suicide doesn't make sense. If the movie had done a more thorough job of foreshadowing the death, or developing more grievous circumstances, perhaps this plot hole would not be as evident to audience members.

In its entirety, Dead Poets Society promotes an enhanced perspective on life that we all like to hear . It challenges us to seize the day and adopt a contemplative mindset. However the way this message is addressed could use some work. The monologues are wonderfully worded, but it seems that they only serve to masquerade over the fact that there are both character and plot development flaws in the movie. Unlike the poetry that these boys drool over, this movie is nothing but a people-pleasing prose parade.

I’m not typically a big fan of coming-of-age dramas, so trying to fathom why Dead Poets Society works so well for me is hard. A big part of it is that Robin Williams is so wonderful as the teacher who inspires these young men to live their lives to the fullest. I find myself so enthralled in the struggles of all these characters after his amazing speeches serve as an inciting incident. Then I just sit in awe as I watch how each boy is changed (or not changed) by the events in the film. There are so many scenes that I find impactful, and I could watch them completely independent of the rest of the movie and they would still give me chills or bring me to tears. If I were to make any complaint it would be a nitpick, but it would probably be that there seems to be a few scenes missing that could more effectively work through the arc of Ethan Hawke’s character. There are a few moments that don’t seem fully earned, because he’s not the most active player in the events of the film even though he is treated like a protagonist. I don’t notice it, though, because I find Dead Poets Society to be so thoroughly enjoyable in all other ways. I never would have thought that a movie so heavily focused on poetry would be one of my all-time favorites, but it is so powerful that I find myself wanting to read poems even though I hated that stuff when I was in school. It takes a special kind of movie to inspire an audience member to seek out things that he ordinarily dislikes.
